title: MoMA | The Collection | Ryuichi Yamashiro. Forest. 1954
content:
Prompted by Altaira's new year's kawai wish card ( [http://typophile.com/node/65762](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104647/http:/typophile.com/node/65762 "http://typophile.com/node/65762")), and by Hrant's quiz about the glyph used for the trees, I was reminded of one of my all time favourite calligraphy/typography posters.

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104647im_/http:/typophile.com/files/tumblr_kuzyb2BWwg1qa8vs1o1_500_5138.jpg)  
 [http://www.moma.org/collection/browse\_results.php?criteria=O%3AAD%3AE%3A...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317104647/http:/www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3AAD%3AE%3A6487&page_number=1&template_id=1&sort_order=1 "http://www.moma.org/collection/browse\_results.php?criteria=O%3AAD%3AE%3A6487&page\_number=1&template\_id=1&sort\_order=1")
author: riccard0

comments.content:
This is great. Way to exploit the potential of an ideographic script. Is this a text or a picture? :-)

(For the uninitiated:  
森 _mori_ = forest  
林 _hayashi_ = also forest, I think a smaller forest?  
where 木 _ki_ = tree)

<cite>林 hayashi = also forest, I think a smaller forest?</cite>

I think it could be translated as "wood".
